title: FADEC / FLI / Needle split
summary: Know what the indications mean (cause vs effect): FADEC FAIL vs FLI FAIL.
Use consistent language: call 'needle split', not 'TQ split'.
Be solid on 80% N1 (~30% TQ) and combined gearbox limit logic.
Prioritise immediate actions, then stabilise, then diagnose.
tre_looks_for: Clear diagnosis narrative ('what I have / what I suspect / what I'm doing').
Correct end-state: stable Nr, known power setting, safe continuation/landing plan.
Sensible CRM: tell TFO/ATC what you’re doing and why.
common_pickups: Chasing captions / tones instead of stabilising first.
Calling the wrong split ('TQ split') or misunderstanding FLI as a fault itself.
sim_patterns: Multiple captions + no cancellation of warner → workload spike.
Throttle button position surprises after twist-grip rotation.

title: Electrical fire / smoke / black cockpit thinking
summary: Treat as time-critical: IAs first, then decide how much diagnosis is worth doing.
Know what you lose with gens off and what you still have (handheld, iPad).
Expect caption overload; keep the workcycle simple.
tre_looks_for: Good captaincy: early intentions, prioritise survivability over neat diagnosis.
Understanding of load-sharing / why bus-ties are opened.
common_pickups: Late ATC/TFO brief before progressing to total DC.
Over-complicating diagnosis when scenario demands isolation and landing.
sim_patterns: Rapid escalation to total DC while you’re still reading the CAD.
Intercom configuration surprises after gen selection.

title: AFCS / AHRS / Reconfig / SAS (incl ‘red button’ judgement)
summary: Use automation deliberately: Select → Engage → Monitor → Action.
Know the reconfiguration panel actions for common display/sensor failures.
Don’t press the 'red button' unless you intend/accept the consequences.
tre_looks_for: Mode awareness: what’s engaged, what it will do next, what you’ll do if it doesn’t.
Stability management: keep a stable platform before troubleshooting.
Correct use of standby instruments and reconfig logic.
common_pickups: Fighting the aircraft instead of commanding the modes.
Not articulating what you expect the AP to do (or noticing it didn’t).
sim_patterns: AHRS roll fail / PFD weirdness that’s subtle at first.
Pitot/static oddities masquerading as speed control problems.

title: Fuel system failures / degraded fuel quantity
summary: Be clear on what triggers pump cautions (air vs seizure current logic).
Know the progression to F QTY DEGR / FAIL and what you trust next.
Cross-check predicted vs actual fuel during IFR scenarios.
tre_looks_for: Early detection (trend monitoring) and calm decision-making.
Correct use of backups and conservative planning.
Good communication: intentions and landing/diversion decisions.
common_pickups: Not knowing the underlying trigger logic so diagnosis becomes guesswork.
Late fuel situation awareness in busy phases (holds/approaches).
sim_patterns: Fuel leak presented early in SPIFR; examiner watches how quickly you notice.
Cascading fuel filt → engine failure → forced handling.

title: Fire (engine / cabin) and end-state thinking
summary: Know the sequence when pressing the fire button and what indications to expect.
Prioritise landing site selection while doing actions.
Don’t get trapped doing 'perfect' actions while failing to make a plan.
tre_looks_for: Immediate actions done correctly and promptly.
Clear end-state: land ASAP where appropriate; justify decisions.
CRM: tell TFO/ATC early; manage workload.
common_pickups: Delaying landing decision while completing checks.
Trying to cancel bells/tones that are non-cancellable.
sim_patterns: Fire presented during a critical phase (VTOL1/approach) with limited options.
Fire combined with another system fault to force captaincy trade-offs.

title: IFR / SPIFR workcycle (ForeFlight, RAIM, backup plan)
summary: Always have Plan B if GPS fails (pre-load conventional aids).
RAIM check habit: early enough to matter.
Automation philosophy: let AP fly; you manage nav/fuel/briefs.
tre_looks_for: Correct mode choices (IAS vs ALTA/VS per local SOP).
common_pickups: Over-reliance on GPS; no manual nav plan.
Late RAIM check or no stated backup.
sim_patterns: GPS failure mid-route; examiner expects HDG hold + needles.
Go-around confusion: flying the wrong missed approach for the phase.
